Much like poker, the rounds can continue until the participants decide to end it.

—description from the designer

Name: Totolospi
Description:
Totolospi is a traditional race game in the public domain. The game has been played by the Hopi Indians and others in Southwestern North America for generations. (It has been documented in many sources of game research.)

The game is played on a straight track of 11 spaces, each player having but one pawn. By tossing casting sticks or coins, a player's pawn must be moved to the opposite end of the track and back home to win. Hindering this effort is the center space, which can only be occupied by one pawn at a time. There is also a push-your-luck aspect to the game, offering players some strategic choices.

NewVenture Games includes this game in a series of ancient games called "Peg Pastimes." These games are reproduced with wooden boards and pegs, and include a brief history of each game.

Name: Anton Glupsch entdeckt Garmisch-Partenkirchen
Description:
The board is a very colorful map of Garmisch Partenkirchen and surrounding areas. There are locations on the map where a card an be picked up. There are several kinds of cards; hiking cards, site attraction cards, and happy yodeler cards.  The cards give information about local interest points and also have certain tasks the player must complete either by rolling the die or moving to other locations on the board. Players try to collect the most of the different types of cards and get to the top of the Zugspitze.

—user summary

Name: ASCII Empires
Description:
ASCII Empires is a board game in which 1–7 players lead early Mediterranean civilizations through antiquity by advancing science and culture, constructing buildings and interacting through trade or conquest. The game is named for its use of text-based visuals inspired by the 1967 ASCII character encoding standard.

The gameplay can be described as “roll-and-write”. Each civilization's progress in various fields and their production and use of resources are marked on a piece of paper, the Empire sheet. Each turn begins with rolling of five dice. During a brief round of diplomacy, some dice may be rerolled; the players then proceed to use the results to mark their sheets. When any of several possible game end conditions is triggered, points are calculated and the player with the most points wins.

—description from designer

Name: Slam Wars: Wrestling Legends of California
Description:
Slam Wars is a card battle game that celebrates the various wrestling territories that existed from the 1940's until the 1990's. It captures the unique flavor of the territory by using historical wrestlers, tag teams, managers, promoters, announcers and referees. Each Slam Wars set is a standalone game, but can be seamlessly integrated with any other Slam Wars set to form a larger playing pool.

Slam Wars: Wrestling Legends of California comes in a 2-piece full-color dual deck poker box and includes a 20-page full-color instruction guide. There are a total of 90 playing cards:

     44 solo wrestlers
     16 tag teams
     13 stat boosters
     10 common match stipulations 
     6 special grudge match stipulations
     1 championship 


A round of play is called an "event" and consists of 7 matches (4 solo and 3 tag team). Seven match stipulation cards will be exposed, one for each match of the event. Each wrestler and tag team card is rated in 5 different categories (represented by symbols that match the stipulation cards). The objective is to strategically place the cards you were dealt in matches where they can perform the best (i.e. have high ratings). Like a good wrestling booker, you are trying to maximize your wrestler's strengths and minimize their weaknesses. After comparing the stats in that particular category, the card with the higher rating wins the match-up.  Whichever player wins a majority of the 7 matches wins the event and is awarded the championship card. The holder of the championship card has an advantage heading into the next round of play. Much like poker, the rounds can continue until the participants decide to end it.

—description from the designer

Name: The Game of Billionaire
Description:
Players try to have the most money at the end of the game. The board has two tracks'. One is a circle track around a spinner which is used to determine how many spaces the player can move. This circular track is used to collect funds.  Once a player has accumulated $300,000, the player can move to a track along all 4 sides of the board.

This outer track has spaces corresponding to various cities. Players bid in auctions to own a city and be able to build a building in it. Players can also add stories to an existing building. If a player lands on a city space that is owned by another player, the owner must be paid.

There are also 3 stock market spaces on the outer track. Landing on these spaces enables a player to buy a stock certificates which have a monetary value at the end of the game.

—user summary

Name: Final Girl: The Happy Trails Horror
Description:
Final Girl Feature Film Box

Summer camp turns deadly in The Happy Trails Horror. Produced by Evan Derrick, this Feature Film box stars Hans - The Butcher, who murders and feasts on unsuspecting campers. When an unlikely heroine emerges, will it be enough to stop the killing? Don't miss this engrossing film with gorgeous scenes by Director of Photography, Tyler Johnson.

The Core Box, when combined with one of our Feature Film Boxes, has everything you need to play the game. Each Feature Film Box features a unique Killer and and iconic Location, and the more Feature Films you have, the more killer/location combinations you can experience!

Each Feature Film Box is double-sided, with amazingly illustrated covers on the front AND back. Not only that, but the magnetically attached box covers are removable, with the reverse of each functioning as the Killer and Location boards respectively.

NOTE: The 2023 First Printing Correction Pack contained 3 corrected cards:

    EVENT - "Vengeance"
    ITEM - "Bear Trap"
    ITEM - "Fireworks"
